Check out more options for charitable deduction reform here:  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?id=C3424D5D-659B-456C-8520-2813CD5D02BF …

One reform option is to make the charitable deduction more widely available. Perhaps the most common proposal for reform is moving the deduction “above the line,” making it available to both itemizers and non-itemizers.

Under current policy, non-itemizers are fully taxed on income that they give away to charitable causes (and itemizers are taxed on some of that income). This treatment is unfair, discourages giving, and weakens civil society.

The drawback is that the deduction doesn't apply to all taxpayers. That it disproportionately goes to higher-income taxpayers is a consequence of its design but not itself an intrinsic flaw. Giving ought to be safeguarded against taxation among lower-class Americans as well.

The after-tax price of giving (the value of donations minus the deduction) declines with income. Thus, even if low- and high-income taxpayers donated the same amount and itemized, the latter would still receive a greater charitable deduction. pic.twitter.com/8c0Ec8sRHp

However, because itemizers tend to have higher incomes, the charitable deduction overwhelmingly goes to higher-income taxpayers. Over 56% of the charitable giving that avoided taxation because of the deduction came from the top 1% of Americans. pic.twitter.com/g1rAxgGjrB

The charitable deduction allows itemizers to deduct the value of their charitable contributions to qualifying tax-exempt organizations, up to 60% of adjusted gross income (AGI). In 2018, the charitable deduction for individuals reduced federal revenue by $54.1 billion.

#Work: Less time with coworkers off the job, little change in commuting time, more work among women, less work among men, more “alternative work arrangements,” part-time or part-year work no more common, longer job tenure, less union membership, more occupational licensing.

#Community: Less time with neighbors, no less time with friends, less racial segregation, more class segregation, less trust generally and in institutions but no less trust in friends or local government, no less volunteering, less voting, mixed trends on political engagement.
#Religion: Lower membership and attendance, fewer raised in a religious tradition, less confidence in organized religion.
#Family: Fewer living in families, no less time spent with our families, later marriage and childbearing, fewer children, more single parenthood.

Though inactive men are relatively unlikely to have children, when they do, they're more likely than employed fathers to have children outside the home. Yet they are less likely to pay child support to the mothers of those children. ⬇️ pic.twitter.com/E0w9YAaqTQ

Since a criminal record impedes the ability to find a job, it is possible that many ex-convicts have withdrawn from the labor force out of frustration. Or it could just be that many men who commit crimes are more likely to have characteristics that make them undesirable hires.

Inactive men are much more likely to have been incarcerated than employed men. Over one-third of inactive men have been incarcerated, including nearly half of disabled men and over a third of "other" inactive men.  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=D72FFEAB-DE2D-4F2C-9BCD-670B9B1BE9C3 … pic.twitter.com/u82sVk6LIn

Religious communities are an important source of social connection. Inactive men are more likely to say that their religious beliefs are very important than are employed men. 
These charts break this down by church attendance and religious affiliation 👇🏼 pic.twitter.com/I6F2yeJjSs

Inactive men spend nearly 30% of their time alone, compared with 18% for prime age, employed men. A substantial portion of the waking hours of inactive men is taken up by television, video games, and electronic devices. pic.twitter.com/V7077edA3B
This disconnectedness suggests that workplace ties are not being replaced by relationships inactive men have outside of work. One reason for that is that inactive men are more likely to live alone.

Compared with employed men, prime-age inactive men are twice as likely to say that they don’t often get invited to do things with others, that it would be difficult to find someone to help them with a move, and that there is no one to share worries and fears with.

While inactive men are about as likely as employed men to have worked in government or the Armed Forces in their most recent position, students and (especially) retirees are disproportionately comprised of men previously holding those occupations.  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=D72FFEAB-DE2D-4F2C-9BCD-670B9B1BE9C3 …

The chart below shows that inactive men are more likely than employed men to have worked in a blue-collar job as their last occupation. That is only true, however, of disabled and "other" inactive men. pic.twitter.com/NFZ8Dxd4wf

Inactive men have lower educational attainment than employed men or men generally. Notably, one in three disabled men does not have a high school education. Also, over the past 20 years, inactivity rose most among men with a high school diploma but no bachelor’s degree. pic.twitter.com/ZDKvv1wrar

Another 23% had experienced an unemployment spell of a month or more in the previous year. We can conclude that just one in four prime-age inactive men spent time looking for work in the preceding year.
More typically, inactive men neither worked in the previous twelve months, nor had any month-long spell of unemployment. That was true of 58% of them.
While 90% of employed men worked in the previous twelve months and had no unemployment spell lasting a month, that was true of just 19% of inactive men. pic.twitter.com/x0JInLBMtA

Contrary to the common view that most of these men have "dropped out" of the labor force after becoming discouraged by the job market, few prime-age inactive men indicate this to be true, and only 12% indicate in household surveys that they want a job or are open to taking one.

Roughly 15% of inactive men are in school, 5 to 10% are retired, and another 5 to 10% are homemakers or caregivers. About a quarter of prime-age inactive men do not fit any of the above 👆🏼 categories.
In 2013, 11% of prime-age men were outside the labor force. Why? Roughly 45% of them indicate that their current situation involves illness or disability. pic.twitter.com/1Vr7bOcODH

We will need new data if we want to compare today’s loneliness levels to those of the past. Unless we ask survey respondents the same questions that were asked in past surveys, we will never know whether loneliness is on the rise.

Loneliness is certainly a problem for whom it chronically persists, and it might be a problem in the United States generally, but the first order of business must be understanding the scale and characteristics of the challenge.

The loneliness discussion has suggested to media consumers and policymakers that it has increased substantially and is a pressing problem. 
These claims are based on a flawed interpretation of the research literature. There is little evidence that loneliness has increased.

It is entirely possible that loneliness has increased over time, but the available evidence does not appear to support that claim. It is just as possible that loneliness has stayed the same or even declined.

The claim that loneliness has doubled since the 1980s is hard to substantiate. The polling questions through the decades are all different from each other. The threshold for being "lonely" also varies by study. This inconsistency raises questions of reliability.
These estimates are hardly conclusive evidence that loneliness has been mostly stable since the early 1960s, but they cast significant doubt on the claim that it has risen significantly.

***Caveats: [1] It’s unwise to assess trends using data points from different polling organizations, which have their own methods. [2] Current events may have affected the NORC polls. The 1963 poll was conducted just after JFK’s assassination; the 2001 poll shortly after 9/11.

In 1985 and 2000, Harris polls found that respondents' experience of loneliness in the past month did not rise over the period, remaining under 20% in both years. Between 1963 and 2001, NORC surveys show a slight decline in reported feelings of loneliness, from 28 to 25%. pic.twitter.com/xPWL4wWyfw
From reading the headlines, one would certainly get the impression that loneliness is increasing. However, it is not at all clear that loneliness has increased over the last several decades.

One important question is whether Americans are increasingly alone (have fewer social contacts or less social interaction). Another question is whether Americans are increasingly experiencing loneliness ("perceived social isolation").
